IRBs issued for a year are consolidated as two Cumulative Bulletins (CB). (

) Although the IRB is the authoritative instrument of the Commissioner for and lishing revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and announcements, may be beneﬁcial to immediately release certain publications directly to the news media for faster public dissemination. In these situations, the Media Relations office should be contacted. (

) A news release may be appropriate in those situations in which there is a niﬁcant need to alert the general news media (as distinguished from the commercial tax services and the ﬁnancial, professional, and trade that routinely disseminate information published in the IRB). The issuance news release is, however, supplemental to, and not in lieu of, publication IRB. Maintaining the integrity of an orderly publication system through the contributes signiﬁcantly to good tax administration. Therefore, the of news releases should be limited to those circumstances in which the clearly justiﬁed. (

) Official publications published by the Service provide information and for taxpayers, Service personnel, and others. Their purpose is to help Revenue personnel apply the tax laws correctly and uniformly and to help taxpayers untarily comply with the tax laws. Notices, and (
) Each publication has its own general characteristics and uses. To ensure sistency, care should be taken to select the appropriate vehicle for disseminating information to the public. (

) Attorneys must consider the appropriate form of guidance and document decision to use that form of guidance in the related ﬁle. Factors to when determining the appropriate form of guidance may include, but are limited to, the following: • The purpose of the guidance and the possible guidance alternatives • The scope of the guidance’s application • The effect on taxpayer’s rights • The effect on taxpayer’s duties • The degree of deference needed for the guidance • Whether the guidance will be controversial • Whether public comments are necessary or helpful • Longevity of the guidance • Whether the guidance should include the application of law to a scenario • Advantages of the type of guidance selected (
) Questions regarding the appropriate document may be directed toward Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration). (

) Revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and announcements are only by the national office and are published in the IRB. IRBs issued for a calendar year are consolidated as two Cumulative Bulletins (CB). (

In these situations, the Service’s Media Relations office should be contacted. (

) A news release may be appropriate in those situations in which there is a niﬁcant need to alert the general news media (as distinguished from the commercial tax services and the ﬁnancial, professional, and trade that routinely disseminate information published in the IRB). The issuance of news release is, however, supplemental to, and not in lieu of, publication in IRB. Maintaining the integrity of an orderly publication system through the contributes signiﬁcantly to good tax administration. Therefore, the of news releases should be limited to those circumstances in which the need clearly justiﬁed. (

32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
) Following the rules and procedures in the Publication Handbook ensures pliance with the various statutory and administrative requirements. See
Procedural Requirements for Regulations; The Legal File, and
, File Management; Guidelines for Speciﬁc Categories of Case Files.
) A revenue ruling is an official interpretation by the Service of the Internal (

) Revenue Code, related statutes, tax treaties, and regulations. It is the Revenue Ruling Deﬁned sion of the Service on how the law is applied to a speciﬁc set of facts. For further information, see section
) of the Statement of Procedural Rules.
) A revenue procedure is an official statement of a procedure by the Service (

) affects the rights or duties of taxpayers or other members of the public under Revenue Procedure the Internal Revenue Code, related statutes, tax treaties, and regulations, or Deﬁned information that, although not necessarily affecting the rights and duties of public, should be a matter of public knowledge.
) A notice is a public pronouncement by the Service that may contain (

) that involves substantive interpretations of the Internal Revenue Code or Notice Deﬁned provisions of the law. Notices may be used in circumstances in which a revenue ruling or revenue procedure would not be appropriate. In addition, notices may be used to solicit public comments on issues under in connection with non-regulatory guidance, such as a proposed revenue procedure. A notice also can be used to relate what regulations will say in ations in which the regulations may not be published in the immediate future.
) An announcement is a public pronouncement that has only immediate or

) An announcement is a public pronouncement that has only immediate or short- term value. For example, an announcement can be used to summarize the law or regulations without making any substantive interpretation or to notify taxpayers of the existence of an election or an approaching deadline for making an election. (

) A news release is a nontechnical publication targeted at the nonpractitioner public through the general news media. A news release is appropriate if the matter is likely to be covered in a major newspaper. Because news releases are, in effect, proposed articles for these newspapers to run, technical discus- sion must be kept to a minimum, and material like Internal Revenue Code section numbers is generally relegated to the end of the article, far away from the lead. News releases are not published in the IRB. (

) News releases are generally drafted by the staff of the Service’s Media Relations office, but may be reviewed by Chief Counsel personnel. The Media Relations staff can often provide helpful guidance regarding whether a news release is appropriate. (
) The decision to disseminate information in the form of a news release must be approved at the Associate Chief Counsel or higher level.
An announcement is a public pronouncement that has only immediate or short

term value. For example, an announcement can be used to summarize the law or regulations without making any substantive interpretation or to notify taxpayers of the existence of an election or an approaching deadline for making an election.
The decision to disseminate information in the form of a news release must be approved at the Associate Chief Counsel or higher level.
Summary of the Published Guidance Process 32.2.2

) Revenue rulings and revenue procedures are alike in that both are issued by the national office and both are for the information and guidance of taxpayers, Service personnel, and others concerned. One numerical series and used for revenue rulings and another is used for revenue procedures. an item is published as a revenue ruling or revenue procedure depends on content. (

) The revenue ruling series is used to set forth statements of Service position to interpret the law with respect to particular tax issues. The revenue procedure series is used to announce statements of procedure or general structional information. A holding on a substantive tax issue to the effect that taxpayers must meet some procedural requirement is a statement of position and is not the proper subject for a revenue procedure. (

) Generally, a revenue ruling states a Service position, whereas a revenue procedure provides instructions concerning a Service position that enable taxpayers to achieve a particular result. For example, a revenue ruling may hold that taxpayers may deduct certain automobile expenses, and a procedure may provide the procedures that eligible taxpayers must follow to compute the amount of the deduction by using certain mileage rates in lieu determining actual operating expenses. (

) A revenue ruling does not ordinarily include a statement of Service practice procedure, and a revenue procedure does not ordinarily include a statement Service position on a substantive tax issue. When a matter involves both a statement of Service position on a substantive tax issue and a statement of practice or procedure, it normally requires the issuance of both a revenue ruling and a revenue procedure. They should be issued simultaneously and should be cross-referenced. (

) In certain circumstances it may be appropriate to include limited procedural guidance in a revenue ruling or provide a holding on substantive tax issues a revenue procedure. For example, a revenue ruling that holds that certain expenses are deductible, rather than subject to capitalization, may contain a procedure for taxpayers to change their method of accounting to conform to the holding of the revenue ruling. In certain cases a revenue procedure can provide a holding on substantive tax issues where it sets forth safe harbors, guidelines, or conditions. See Rev. Proc.
These situations should be rare and the general rule stated in paragraph (
) should usually be followed. (

32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
) The need for published guidance can be identiﬁed from a number of and external sources. The procedures in this Handbook should be followed regardless of the source. a (
) An important consideration in evaluating potential publication projects is the need to eliminate impediments to electronic ﬁling. (

) Issues to be published are identiﬁed from many sources, including, but not limited to: • Issues in various types of cases, such as technical advice and letter rulings • Comments and suggestions from the Commissioner and other personnel • Comments and suggestions from taxpayers, practitioners, outside nizations (including issues raised through the industry issues program), tax publications and periodicals, continuing legal programs for tax professionals, and other comments on tax law at professionals or the taxpaying public • Comments and suggestions from the Chief Counsel, Deputy Chief Counsel, Associate Chief Counsel, and Division Counsel (and their staffs), and from Treasury personnel • Announcements of acquiescence or nonacquiescence on Tax Court opinions • Chief Counsel Notices bearing the title “CHANGE IN LITIGATION POSITION” (“CLP”) • Recently enacted legislation • Common issues in private letter ruling requests (Associate Chief Counsel offices should annually review the uniform issue list codes related to private letter rulings issued during the past year to whether the issuance of published guidance may be appropriate for of the common issues in these requests) (

) Each year the IRS and Treasury develop a Guidance Priority List (GPL), is also sometimes referred to as the Priority Guidance Plan (or “business List plan”). The GPL identiﬁes the issues that will be addressed in published guidance during the business plan year. The IRS and Treasury solicit mendations from the public for items that should be included on the GPL. IRS and Treasury also consider recommendations from within the Service, Office of Chief Counsel, and other government agencies. Interested parties may submit recommendations for guidance at any time during the year. (
) The GPL may be updated periodically. These updates provide the IRS and

) Each year the IRS and Treasury develop a Guidance Priority List (GPL), is also sometimes referred to as the Priority Guidance Plan (or “business plan”). The GPL identiﬁes the issues that will be addressed in published guidance during the business plan year. The IRS and Treasury solicit recom- mendations from the public for items that should be included on the GPL. IRS and Treasury also consider recommendations from within the Service, Office of Chief Counsel, and other government agencies. Interested parties may submit recommendations for guidance at any time during the year. (

) The GPL may be updated periodically. These updates provide the IRS and Treasury with greater ﬂexibility to address the need for additional guidance may arise during the business plan year resulting from new legislation, changes in policy, or other emerging circumstances. If new projects must be added during the business plan year, the Office of Chief Counsel and may have to reevaluate which projects must be published and those for publication may be deferred. As the need arises, the IRS and Treasury work on published guidance projects that do not appear on the GPL.
Published Guidance Process

) The Office of Chief Counsel receives suggestions for published guidance many sources within the IRS, as well as from external sources, such as the American Bar Association, the Tax Executives Institute, and the American Institute of Certiﬁed Public Accountants. These suggestions should be given serious consideration in the process of selecting and prioritizing guidance tiatives for inclusion in the annual Guidance Priority List. In addition, each Associate Chief Counsel office should strongly consider issuing published guidance concerning substantially similar matters that are repeated subjects private letter ruling requests, technical assistance memoranda, or other requests for legal advice. (

) The IRS and Treasury annually publish a Notice inviting recommendations from the public for items to be included on the GPL for the upcoming year. Notice usually is published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin in late April or May, and seeks comments by the end of May, but also reminds the public suggestions may be submitted to the IRS at any time during the year. In addition to the Internal Revenue Bulletin, the Notice is posted on the IRS website, and is published in the popular tax press, as well as on scores of publicly accessible Internet web sites. (

) To facilitate the appropriate consideration of these suggestions, the Publica- tions and Regulations Branch, Legal Processing Division, in the Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration), will forward to the appropriate Associate office the stakeholder suggestions for published guidance sent to the Office of Chief Counsel. (

) Suggestions for published guidance from external sources that are received directly by attorneys or Associate offices should be sent to the Publications Regulations Branch. The Publications and Regulations Branch will acknowl- edge receipt of all suggestions for published guidance received from sources and will maintain a ﬁle of these suggestions. (

) Each Associate office should maintain organized ﬁles regarding requests for published guidance from both internal and external sources that involve within that office’s subject matter jurisdiction. These ﬁles should be in a way that facilitates retrieval of suggestions for consideration in selecting and prioritizing issues to be included on a future Guidance Priority List or an update to the list. Each suggestion, whether from internal or external stake- holders, should be evaluated in light of the criteria described in CCDM
, and each Associate office should document the reasons for its decision to recommend for or against inclusion of a suggestion on the GPL. (

) When selecting projects for the GPL, the IRS and Treasury consider the following: • Whether the recommended guidance resolves signiﬁcant issues to many taxpayers • Whether the guidance may be appropriate for enhanced public ment through the process described in Notice

• Whether the recommended guidance promotes sound tax • Whether the recommended guidance can be drafted in a manner that will enable taxpayers to understand and apply the guidance easily • Whether the IRS can enforce the recommended guidance on a basis Chief Counsel Directives Manual

) Matters should be recommended for publication only if they meet at least of the foregoing criteria. Note: A subject that is primarily a determination of fact rather than an of law should not ordinarily be recommended for publication, even though the subject meets one or more of the above publication criteria. (

) In addition to the factors described above, the IRS and Treasury consider whether the guidance is required by statute, the number of taxpayers by the proposed guidance, and the resources available to complete all the guidance projects proposed for a particular year. The IRS and Treasury to include the most important suggestions for guidance on the GPL each (

Signiﬁcant Impact on Taxpayers or Tax Exempt Organizations . An issue affects a signiﬁcant number of taxpayers if a large number of taxpayers need the conclusion in order to prepare their tax returns or to comply with the tax laws. The issue would meet this standard even its revenue impact is minor for an individual taxpayer. Such issues publication and are typically later incorporated into Publication

, Your Federal Income Tax. On the other hand, issues not currently answered statute, regulations, or revenue rulings, that affect few taxpayers or an obvious application of an existing published principle, are of importance or interest to warrant publication. b. Substantial Segment of Industry(ies). An issue may qualify under this criterion even though the industry has a small number of entities. What important is that the IRS notify all entities in the industry simultaneously a newly established position. For example, in the excise tax area, a ruling to one company that a product line is nontaxable would give that company a major competitive advantage over other entities producing same product. Thus, there may be a publishable issue even though are only a few entities affected and the aggregate revenue involved is great. c. Signiﬁcant Impact Upon Revenue. An issue may qualify for this if it will have a signiﬁcant impact upon revenue. It includes the

published in the IRB, or by an open publication project) and has a signiﬁcant issue as indicated below. a. Signiﬁcant Impact on Taxpayers or Tax Exempt Organizations . An issue affects a signiﬁcant number of taxpayers if a large number of taxpayers need the conclusion in order to prepare their tax returns or to comply with the tax laws. The issue would meet this standard even its revenue impact is minor for an individual taxpayer. Such issues publication and are typically later incorporated into Publication

, Your Federal Income Tax. On the other hand, issues not currently answered statute, regulations, or revenue rulings, that affect few taxpayers or an obvious application of an existing published principle, are of importance or interest to warrant publication. b. Substantial Segment of Industry(ies). An issue may qualify under this criterion even though the industry has a small number of entities. What is important is that the IRS notify all entities in the industry simultaneously a newly established position. For example, in the excise tax area, a letter ruling to one company that a product line is nontaxable would give that company a major competitive advantage over other entities producing the same product. Thus, there may be a publishable issue even though there are only a few entities affected and the aggregate revenue involved is not great. c. Signiﬁcant Impact Upon Revenue. An issue may qualify for this if it will have a signiﬁcant impact upon revenue. It includes the publication of issues derived from letter rulings and technical advice. d. Invalid Tax Transactions. An issue may qualify under this criterion if it includes anticipating invalid tax shelters and tax schemes and taking prompt action to prevent proliferation of these transactions, rather than waiting to deal with them at a later time in the return examination e. Signiﬁcant Legal Issue. An issue may qualify under this criterion if it addresses a signiﬁcant legal issue. It includes deﬁnitions of basic concepts, such as partnerships, associations, trusts, and similar terms if clariﬁcation is needed, even though revenue impact may be minimal. standard would also apply to clariﬁcation of regulation or treaty f. The following are examples of matters the Service is required by law or regula- tion to publish. Under section

, the Service periodically publishes the interest rates applicable to tax deﬁciencies and refunds. In the municipal bond area, the Service periodically publishes several different statistical tables setting forth safe harbors, state ceilings, and similar data.
Recommendations for proposed publications should be made in the manner provided by the Associate office to which the recommendation is being

If a project warrants publication but the appropriate format cannot yet be deter- mined it can be opened with the CASE category Published Guidance/ Proposals and Studies (PGP). This category is also appropriate for preparing or reviewing special studies of technical issues that require extensive research and cannot be handled in the normal course of operations. For example, a case can be opened under this category to determine whether a publication is needed on a particular tax issue. Projects under this category must be
32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
approved by the Associate Chief Counsel. If a recommendation warrants further consideration or study, a publication project may be opened in order explore the issues raised in the recommendation. (

) In those cases in which the proposed publication is based upon an letter ruling or technical advice, it must be titled by reference to the primary issue addressed (a generic title) rather than to the taxpayer’s name, for example, “Corporate Continuance Statutes” not “Smith Corp.” A notice or an- nouncement project should include the type of guidance in the title since publications are opened with the CASE category NOT. If the name of the project contains a reference to another publication, then the new project should begin with the identiﬁcation of that publication, for example, “Rev.
, Revocation of” rather than “Revocation of Rev. Rul.

) The drafting attorney is responsible for ensuring that a publication project is updated to reﬂect milestones during the development of the publication and closed in accordance with the CASE-MIS handbook. (
) Each Associate office is required to enter status report and progress updates into CASE-MIS. (
) In August

, the Office of Chief Counsel issued new Business Plan Tracking Instructions describing the procedures for tracking published projects in CASE-MIS. The Business Plan Tracking Instructions are available on the F&M Chief Counsel Intranet website under Planning and Finance, Systems Coordination Branch. The instructions reﬂect revisions made to CASE-MIS to more accurately describe the status of published guidance projects and to capture target and milestone dates. (

) Two new reports are available on CASE-MIS to track the progress of guidance projects. The Business Plan Status Report reﬂects milestone dates and other relevant information, and may be generated using various values provide customized information. The Business Plan Mandatory Date Report allows users to quickly see which cases need immediate action based on parameters selected by the user. (
) The Office of Chief Counsel uses various milestones to manage the guidance process. Those milestones are reﬂected in the revised status described in the August

Business Plan Tracking Instructions. These stones assist in identifying whether a published guidance project is on track be issued by its target publication date. Only the dates for “interim described in CCDM

, must be estimated and tracked on CASE- MIS. The other steps in the published guidance process described in more detail below also may be appropriate for tracking the progress of particular projects. The formal interim milestones set forth in CCDM

are not intended to be used as inﬂexible deadlines. Rather, it is understood that target dates are changed for a variety of reasons inherent in the published guidance process. Ultimately it is more important for the Associate offices to meet the target publication dates of the individual projects over interim milestone date projections, and that an annual measurement is a more accurate reﬂection of the relative success of the Associate office in guidance than a measurement of whether interim milestones have been met. ) In addition to the mandatory green circulation draft, each Associate office consider one or more of the following steps to complement the milestones tracked on CASE-MIS: • Issues memorandum • Coordination with other offices before initial circulation draft • Initial circulation draft • Coordination with Treasury on material issues • Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng (

) Associate offices should identify which of these steps may be appropriate for each project and establish target dates for completion. Except for the green circulation draft, whether any speciﬁc step described below is appropriate for project is within the judgment and discretion of the Associate office. The taken and the order in which they are completed will be governed by factors such as the complexity of the project and type of guidance being issued, as well as the relationship a particular office has with Treasury and the ing IRS operating divisions. It is anticipated that the need for particular steps will be revisited throughout the plan year as published guidance projects progress towards completion and as developments arise. (

) These interim milestones and steps, in conjunction with the target date, should provide an early warning of whether delays are being encoun- tered with respect to a project, without imposing an undue administrative burden on the Associate office. Progress on these milestones, speciﬁcally, whether and which of the interim milestones have been completed, when viewed in relation to the target publication date, will assist in determining projects are subject to delay. (

) The preparation of an issues memorandum is strongly encouraged for all published guidance projects. Ideally, an issues memorandum will be prepared at a relatively early stage in the process, preferably before any sig- niﬁcant drafting has been done. For certain more complex projects, it may desirable to prepare additional issues memoranda as the project progresses reﬂect newly identiﬁed issues and recommendations or signiﬁcant revisions the previously identiﬁed issues and recommendations. This may be ate, for example, in advance of a Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng. (

) There is no prescribed format for the issues memorandum and the level of detail is left to the discretion of the Associate office. In general, however, the issues memorandum should identify the signiﬁcant issues raised in the and should include an analysis and recommended resolution. The issues memorandum should present alternative and opposing positions, as well as whether coordination with speciﬁc offices is needed to prepare a circulation draft. Preparation of an issues memorandum will assist the Associate office determining which other steps would be appropriate for the project, such as whether coordination should occur prior to circulation of a draft or whether a Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng will be needed. (

) This step will be considered to have been completed when the initial issues memorandum is approved by the Associate Chief Counsel. In general, this step should be completed well before the target publication date.
projects are subject to delay. (

) The preparation of an issues memorandum is strongly encouraged for virtually all published guidance projects. Ideally, an issues memorandum will be prepared at a relatively early stage in the process, preferably before any sig- niﬁcant drafting has been done. For certain more complex projects, it may be desirable to prepare additional issues memoranda as the project progresses to reﬂect newly identiﬁed issues and recommendations or signiﬁcant revisions to the previously identiﬁed issues and recommendations. This may be appropri- ate, for example, in advance of a Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng. (

) There is no prescribed format for the issues memorandum and the level of detail is left to the discretion of the Associate office. In general, however, the issues memorandum should identify the signiﬁcant issues raised in the project and should include an analysis and recommended resolution. The issues memorandum should present alternative and opposing positions, as well as whether coordination with speciﬁc offices is needed to prepare a circulation draft. Preparation of an issues memorandum will assist the Associate office in determining which other steps would be appropriate for the project, such as whether coordination should occur prior to circulation of a draft or whether a Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng will be needed. (

) This step will be considered to have been completed when the initial issues memorandum is approved by the Associate Chief Counsel. In general, this step should be completed well before the target publication date.

This step will be considered to have been completed when the initial issues memorandum is approved by the Associate Chief Counsel. In general, this step should be completed well before the target publication date.
32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook

) This step is designed to ensure that the Associate office coordinates with Associate offices, Division Counsel or IRS functions that are either directly with Other affected by an issue in the project or with subject matter jurisdiction over an Initial issue in the project. This coordination may be formal or informal and should prior to any widespread circulation of a draft. It is expected that the coordina- tion contemplated by this step will ordinarily occur at the developmental stage of the process, such as during the preliminary draft or precirculation stage. It recognized, however, that this step may be appropriate more than once the course of the project, since the need for additional coordination with other offices may arise as the project progresses. In this regard, the circulation of preliminary drafts to a wider audience is strongly encouraged. Required nation with other offices is discussed in CCDM
, Coordination and Clearance. (
) This step is mandatory for all published guidance projects. The circulation is discussed in CCDM

, General Circulation. This step is intended to Draft provide offices that are not involved in the development of a project with a meaningful opportunity for comment. The existing practice in some offices has been to only do a general circulation shortly before the expected publication the project. This practice tends to minimize any meaningful opportunity for comment by functions that were not previously involved in the drafting and frequently results in consternation and resistance on the part of the ing Associate office when comments are received late in the game that may delay or derail the project. Consequently, the circulation of preliminary drafts a wider audience is strongly encouraged. Moreover, the circulation draft ordinarily be circulated several months prior to the date the Associate office anticipates beginning the formal approval process for the publication package. Depending on the nature and extent of the comments received, it is appropriate to circulate additional drafts prior to beginning the publication age approval process. (

) This step will be considered to have been completed when a draft is widely circulated outside the Associate office responsible for the project. In general, the target date for this step should be about two to four months prior to the target publication date. (

) This step entails soliciting input from Treasury regarding material issues in the project. Materials issues are those issues requiring direction from Treasury in With order to meaningfully move the project towards completion. Ideally, this nation will occur at a relatively early stage in the process. It is recognized, however, that this step may be appropriate more than once during the course of the project, since the need for additional coordination with Treasury may arise as the project progresses and additional issues are identiﬁed and developed. This step differs from the joint brieﬁng milestone described in CCDM
in that the coordination contemplated in this step is generally informal and is at a level below the Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy. (

) This step is appropriate when a decision is needed by the Chief Counsel or Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy regarding policy or other signiﬁcant issues or Joint the project. A Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng is often used to resolve conﬂicts. In some complex projects, more than one Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng may be needed. A Chief Counsel or joint brieﬁng is a formal brieﬁng at which all Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
V

) This step is designed to ensure that the Associate office coordinates with other Associate offices, Division Counsel or IRS functions that are either directly with Other affected by an issue in the project or with subject matter jurisdiction over an Initial issue in the project. This coordination may be formal or informal and should be Draft prior to any widespread circulation of a draft. It is expected that the coordina- tion contemplated by this step will ordinarily occur at the developmental stage of the process, such as during the preliminary draft or precirculation stage. It is recognized, however, that this step may be appropriate more than once during the course of the project, since the need for additional coordination with other offices may arise as the project progresses. In this regard, the circulation of preliminary drafts to a wider audience is strongly encouraged. Required coordi- nation with other offices is discussed in CCDM
, Coordination and Clearance.

Business Plan Tracking Instructions describe revised milestone ﬁelds on CASE-MIS. While interim milestone dates are not mandatory, they are required for all Guidance Priority List items. The revised milestone date ﬁelds are: Green Sheet, Pink Sheet, CC Review, Review, OTP Review. It is expected that target dates for the interim that are considered appropriate for the project will be established near the beginning of the business plan year or shortly after a project is opened, for projects that are begun during the business plan year. Each target date is sidered met when a project enters the next appropriate status, and once the appropriate status code is entered the checkbox next to the milestone is matically populated. The ﬁeld can be updated but the checkbox will remain checked. For example, if a case that reached status
(Pink Sheet) extensive rewriting, you may put the status back to

(Green Sheet tion). The new green sheet circulation date will be noted on the case history screen but the green sheet will continue to be shown as completed. Reports will show the last date a project has passed the milestone. (

) Since the interim milestones are intended to be a management tool, not an evaluative tool, the target dates for the milestones may be changed by the Associate office as appropriate. In addition, there is only one target date per interim milestone, which will be overridden whenever a new target date entered for that milestone. (

) If a project is recommended for nonpublication, a memorandum discussing reason for closing the project must be prepared and approved by the ate officials before the project is closed on CASE-MIS. For the format of a nonpublication memorandum, see Exhibit
) The standards for nonpublication of an open guidance project and the concerning what should be included in a nonpublication memorandum are contained in this section. (
) An open publication project may be identiﬁed as an appropriate subject for nonpublication by the drafting attorney or by any person in the review (

) An open publication project may be closed by nonpublication for any of the following reasons: • The matter involves an issue speciﬁcally addressed by another open publication project. • The issue is answered by statute, treaty, or regulations, or will be answered by pending legislation; answered by publications or court opinions previously published in the IRB; involves a determination of fact rather than an interpretation of law; or is of insufficient or interest to warrant publication. • The matter is recommended for nonpublication by an Associate Chief Counsel, a Division Counsel, the Chief Counsel, the Commissioner, by a Treasury official. ) Files closed by nonpublication will be retained in accordance with the control schedule set forth in IRM
, Records Control Schedule for nal Revenue Service for Associate Chief Counsel Offices. (

) Each publication project should be reviewed for its potential effect on prior publications. A publication may be used to effect a change in a prior publica- tion issued in an equal or lower series. A publication may never be used to effect a change in a prior publication issued in a higher series. Regulations would be the highest series, followed by revenue rulings and revenue proce- dures, then notices and announcements, and lastly, news releases. For example, when appropriate, a revenue ruling may be used to modify a ruling, revenue procedure, notice, or announcement. A revenue ruling may never be used to modify a regulation. See CCDM
, Required For- mat for Regulations, for information on the effect of regulations on other publications. (

) When a publication affects a prior publication a separate section with the heading EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS must be used in the new tion. Include the title of the affected document and the effect of the new publication. For example: Rev. Rul.
is modiﬁed and superseded. See

32.2.2.8 (08-11-2004) Effect on Other Documents
Published Guidance Process
page also CCDM
, Effect on Other Revenue Rulings (or Documents), and CCDM
, Effect on Other Revenue Procedures (or Documents). (

) When a proposed publication affects a prior publication, one of the terms (or combination of terms) described below is used. These are the only terms may be used to describe the effect of a publication on a prior publication. (

) Ampliﬁed is used when no change is being made in a prior published but the prior position is being extended to apply to a variation of the facts. Thus, if an earlier publication held that a principle applied to A and the new publication holds that the same principle also applies to B the earlier publica- tion is ampliﬁed. (Compare with modiﬁed, below.) (

) Clariﬁed is used when the language in a prior publication is being made because the language in the prior document has caused, or may cause, confusion. It is not to be used when a position in a prior publication is being changed. (
) Distinguished is used when a proposed publication mentions a prior tion and points out an essential difference between them. (

) Modiﬁed is used when the substance of a previously published position is being changed. Thus, if a prior publication held that a principle applied to A not to B and the new publication holds that it applies to both A and B, the publication is modiﬁed because it changes a published position. should be given to the application of section
). (Compare with ampliﬁed and clariﬁed.) (

) Obsoleted is used when a previous publication is not considered determina- tive with respect to future transactions. This term is used in a revenue ruling that lists previously published revenue rulings that are obsoleted because of changes in law or regulations. A publication also may be obsoleted because the substance has been included in regulations subsequently adopted. (
) Revoked is used when the position in a previous publication is not correct the correct position is being stated in a new publication. Consideration be given to the application of section
) regarding retroactivity. (

) Superseded is used when the new publication does nothing more than the substance and situation of a previous publication (or publications). seded is also used when it is desired to republish in a single publication a series of situations, issues, etc., that were published previously over a period of time in separate publications. Note: If the new publication does more than restate the substance of a prior cation, a combination of terms is required. For example, modiﬁed and superseded describes a situation in which the substance of a previously published ruling is being changed in part and is continued without change part, and it is desired to restate the valid portion of the previous publication in a new self-contained publication. In such a case, the previous ﬁrst is modiﬁed and then, as modiﬁed, is superseded. See also CCDM
, Effect on Other Revenue Rulings (or Documents). (
) Supplemented is used only in situations in which a list, such as a list of the names of countries, is published and that list is expanded by adding names Chief Counsel Directives Manual
of the Published Guidance Process 32.2.2
Distinguished is used when a proposed publication mentions a prior publica- tion and points out an essential difference between them.

If the new publication does more than restate the substance of a prior publi- cation, a combination of terms is required. For example, modiﬁed and superseded describes a situation in which the substance of a previously published ruling is being changed in part and is continued without change in part, and it is desired to restate the valid portion of the previous publication in a new self-contained publication. In such a case, the previous publication ﬁrst is modiﬁed and then, as modiﬁed, is superseded. See also CCDM
, Effect on Other Revenue Rulings (or Documents).
(8) Supplemented is used only in situations in which a list, such as a list of the names of countries, is published and that list is expanded by adding names in
32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook

subsequent publications. After the original publication has been supplemented several times, a new publication should be published to include the list in the original publication and the additions, and all prior publications in the series superseded. (

) Suspended is used only in rare situations to show that previously published guidance will not be applied pending some future action, such as the issuance of new or amended regulations, the outcome of cases in litigation, or the outcome of a Service study. (
) The procedures concerning the responsibilities of persons throughout the cation process will vary depending on the organizational structure and the procedures of the Associate office. (

) The Chief Counsel is responsible for administering a system for publishing revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and announcements in the IRB, and for assisting in the creation of news releases, including standards for and format. (

) The Associate Chief Counsels are responsible for the management and operation of the publications program. The Associate offices are also respon- sible for day-to-day managing of the publications program, monitoring the progress of each proposed publication, and conducting periodic reviews of the publications inventory. The Associate offices prepare periodic status reports, set target dates, prepare memoranda or take other follow-up action needed to move proposed publications through the review process, and coordinate all incoming memoranda from the Chief Counsel, the Commissioner, and with respect to proposed publications in the review process. The Associate offices are also responsible for ensuring that the congressional review of rules reports are completed and timely forwarded to the Publications and Regula- tions Branch for delivery. See CCDM
, Congressional Review of

subsequent publications. After the original publication has been supplemented several times, a new publication should be published to include the list in the original publication and the additions, and all prior publications in the series are superseded.

Suspended is used only in rare situations to show that previously published guidance will not be applied pending some future action, such as the issuance of new or amended regulations, the outcome of cases in litigation, or the outcome of a Service study.

) Taxpayers generally may rely upon revenue rulings and revenue procedures determining their tax treatment if their facts and circumstances are substan- tially the same as those in the revenue ruling or revenue procedure. See Proc.

) and (d), all notices announcements issued by the Service and published in the IRB are authority and the Service is bound by the substantive or procedural provided in a notice or announcement to the same extent as a revenue or revenue procedure. See Rev. Rul.

) Chief Counsel attorneys must follow legal positions established by in papers ﬁled in Tax Court or in defense letters or suit letters sent to DOJ. Chief Counsel attorneys may not rely on case law to take a position that is less favorable to a taxpayer in a particular case than the position set forth in publication. For example, if a revenue ruling provides that a particular may be currently deducted, Chief Counsel attorneys should not challenge deduction even though under the applicable case law, the expense should capitalized.

subject: [Regulation or Other Form of Published Guidance] to be Closed by Nonpublication
